physDesc.p: This is a one page letter. In the Heading penciled in it is written “Poetry (Monroe).”

div.p: This is the proof. There would not be nearly so many alterations if you would stick more closely to my text, which, as I have frequently told you, I prepare with great care. For instance, you have stanza spaces throughout the poem where none existed. I have decided to accept three of these; the others must go. You are quite right about “heeded”. It was a misprint in the manuscript. Some of your other suggestions I have taken, but in most instances I prefer my original method. At any rate, this proof is now correct.

I am awfully sorry to have held you up on it, but I do wish in future you could arrange to send me your proofs with a little more leeway, so that they may be properly done. It seems to me that I am always telegraphing my corrections, and I am sure that that (sic) is quite unnecessary. Of course usually I can send the proof back by return mail. Unfortunately this time I was away from home, and sending it to me and my getting back to where there was a manuscript has made a delay of exactly three days. Had I had a week or so leeway there three days would not have made any difference to you nor to me.
div.P: However, here it is rushed off for the mail, and I hope it will come in time. I will not stop to write a letter with it now. Sincerely yours,
